messages.content: What is the minimum number of workers required for an establishment to be exempt from the provisions of this Act?
Less than five workers
Which establishments and workers are NOT subject to the provisions of Chapter XII, XIII, or XIV of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
[ii] seamen, in the cases other than the case of application of Chapters XII, XIII and XIV; [k] any agricultural farm where normally less than five workers work
What is the effect of sub-section (3) of Section 1 on the applicability of this Act?

This Act shall not apply to establishments or workers specified in clause (a), (b), (c), (d), security printing press, ordnance factory, institutions run for treatment, care, or service of sick, disabled, aged, destitute, handicapped, orphan, abandoned woman or child or widow, but not run for profit or gain
According to Section 1(4), what is the exception in terms of application of this Act to Government servants?

[In the case of application of Chapter II] any shop or industrial or commercial establishment owned and directly operated by the Government where the workers are governed by the conduct rules applicable to the Government servants
What is the definition of 'retirement' in Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The act of leaving employment voluntarily or through any other means, resulting in the cessation of an employee's service
What is the definition of 'partial disablement' under Section 1A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Partial disablement means a temporary or permanent nature of disability that reduces the earning capacity of a worker in any employment where he was engaged at the time of the accident resulting in the disablement.
What is considered as a 'festival allowance' under Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Festival allowance means festival allowance of the workers of factories and establishments which is paid on the occasion of respective religious festivals as determined by the Rules.
Who is considered an 'officer' in the case of a trade union under Section 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
An officer, in the case of a trade union, means any member of the executive committee thereof, but does not include an auditor or legal adviser.
What is the definition of 'working hour' under Section 8 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Working hour means the time during which the workers employed are at the disposal of the employer, excluding any interval allowed for rest and meals.

A factory has a total of 10 workers employed on any day. If one worker is injured in an accident resulting in partial disablement, what percentage of the working hour should be provided as leave to the injured worker?
Refer to Section 29 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, which states that the employer shall provide a leave of not less than 25 days per year for the injured worker due to partial disablement.
What does the term 'subsistence allowance' mean under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
It means half of the basic wages, dearness allowance, and adhoc or interim wages.
How long is an employee entitled to receive gratuity upon termination of service?
30 days for every completed year of service or a period exceeding six months. For employees with more than ten years of service, it's 45 days.
What is the definition of 'retrenchment' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The termination of services of workers by the employer on grounds of redundancy.
An employee is involved in a 'go-slow' action. What does this mean under the Act?
An organized, deliberate, and intentional slowing down of normal output of work by a group of workers, not due to any mechanical defect or other reasons.
What is the meaning of 'trade union federation' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A federation of trade unions registered under Chapter XIII.
What is defined as a 'seaman' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
'Seaman' means seaman of any ocean-going ship, but does not include a master of a ship (Section 23)
Who is considered an 'executive committee' of a trade union under the Act?

'Executive committee', in the case of a trade union, means a body of persons, by whatever name called, to which the management of the affairs of a trade union is entrusted by its constitution (Section 24)
What is considered 'maternity benefit' under the Act?
'Maternity benefit' means the sum of money payable under the provisions of Chapter IV to a woman worker with leave other benefits on the ground of her being a mother (Section 34)
A worker dies due to an accident at work. What type of dependant is entitled to receive compensation?
The widow, minor child, unmarried daughter or a widowed mother of the deceased worker are considered dependants entitled to receive compensation (Section 30(a) and (b))
What is defined as 'dismissal' under the Act, and how can it be terminated?
'Dismissal' means the termination of service of a worker by the employer for misconduct. Dismissal can only be terminated with an order from the Director General or a Labour Inspector (Section 39)
What is considered a commercial establishment under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Any establishment which carries on the business of advertising, commission or forwarding, or any office-establishment of a person who employs workers for implementing a contract with any commercial or industrial establishment.
What is included in the definition of 'wages' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
All remuneration expressed in terms of money, which would be payable to a worker in respect of his employment or work done in such employment.
Who is considered an employer under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any person who employs workers therein, including heirs, guardians, successors, managers, and control authorities, as well as government-appointed authorities.
What is considered a 'lock-out' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A lock-out declared, commenced or continued in contravention of the provisions of Chapter XIV.
Can an employer unilaterally deduct money from an employee's wages for any reason, including house accommodation, light, water, medical facilities, or other amenities?
No. Such deductions are excluded by general or special order by the Government.
Who is considered the competent officer in case of an establishment under the possession of a person other than the owner?

The person in possession of that establishment or the person who is in ultimate control over the affairs of the establishment or the manager or any competent officer who is connected with the management of such activities.
What is considered as 'machinery' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Prime movers, transmission machinery and other appliances whereby power is generated, transformed, transmitted or applied.
A worker is laid off due to a shortage of coal. What does this imply?
The failure, refusal, or inability of an employer to give employment to a worker on account of the specified reasons (shortage of coal).
What is considered as 'lock-out' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The closing of a place of work or a part of such place, or the suspension of work therein, wholly or partly, by an employer, with the intention of compelling workers to accept certain terms and conditions of employment.
What is considered as 'industrial dispute' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any industrial dispute or any matter relating thereto, including disputes arising out of wage rates, working hours, conditions of work, and other terms and conditions of employment.
What type of establishments are covered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The Labour Act 2006 covers industrial establishments that include factories, newspaper establishments, mine, quarry, gas field or oil field, ship-building, plantation, construction, road transport service, and other related businesses.
What is the definition of a 'worker' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

A worker means any person employed in any establishment or industry, either directly or through a contractor, to do any skilled, unskilled, manual, technical, trade promotional, or clerical work for hire or reward.
What is the meaning of 'total disablement' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Total disablement means such disablement, whether of a temporary or permanent nature, that incapacitates a worker for all work which he was capable of performing at the time of the accident resulting in such disablement.

An employee is injured on the job and has been diagnosed with a condition that affects their ability to perform their job duties. What percentage of loss of earning capacity is considered as permanent total disablement under the Labour Act 2006?

Permanent total disablement is deemed to result from the permanent total loss of the sight of both eyes or any combination of injuries specified in the First Schedule, where the aggregate percentage of the loss of earning capacity against those injuries amounts to one hundred percent.
A trade union has filed a complaint with the Labour Court alleging unfair labour practices by an employer. What is the definition of 'industrial dispute' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

An industrial dispute means any dispute or difference of opinion between employers and employers, between employers and workers, or between workers and workers in respect of appointment or conditions of service or conditions of work or environment of work of any person.
What is the definition of a 'newspaper establishment' under Section (71) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
An establishment for printing, production or publication of any newspaper or an establishment run by any news agency or news or feature syndicate.
What are the conditions that a service rule must meet before it can be effective in an establishment, as per Section (3) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The approval of the Inspector General for the establishment.
A worker is supplied by a contracting agency to work in different posts. Is this allowed under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, and if so, what are the conditions?

No, it is not allowed unless the contracting agency is registered by the Government. As per Section (3) of the Act, workers supplied by a contracting agency shall be treated as the workers of the contractor concerned.

What is the maximum period within which an appeal can be made to the Government against the order of the Inspector General regarding service rules, as per Section (4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
30 days from the receipt of the order.
A worker suffers serious bodily injury while working in an establishment. What is considered as 'serious bodily injury' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, and what are the implications?

Any injury that involves or likely to be involved in permanent loss of use of any limb, permanent injury to any limb, permanent loss of sight, permanent injury to hearing, or permanent fracture of any limb, or enforced absence from work for a period exceeding 20 days.
What is considered a probationer under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A worker employed for the time being in an establishment in a permanent post and the period of his probation has not ended.
How long can a skilled worker's probationary period be extended if their work quality within the first three months is not possible to ascertain?
For a further period of three months, as per section (8) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.
What type of worker is entitled to preference in employment based on previous year's experience?
Seasonal workers employed in industries like sugar mills, chatals, etc. and in seasonal workshops.
How should an employer handle a situation where a temporary worker's service is terminated during their probationary period, and they are reappointed by the same employer within three years?
The employee shall be deemed to be a probationer again, and the total period of their previous probation shall be counted for determining the total period of their probation.
What document should an employer provide to every worker before employing them, as per section (5) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
An appointment letter and an identity card with the worker's photograph
What is required of an employer when a worker loses their service book and requests a replacement copy?
The employer shall provide the worker with a copy of the service book at the cost of the worker, as per section (8) of the Act.
Who has the right to keep and maintain a duplicate copy of their service book, and what is the associated cost?
The worker has the right to keep and maintain a duplicate copy of their service book at their own cost, as per section (6) of the Act.
What information must be included in a service book, according to section (2) of the Act?
A service book must contain specific particulars including the worker's name and address, date of birth, designation, department or section, ticket or card, and details of previous employment.
What is required of an employer in terms of maintaining a register of workers, as per section (1) of the Act?
The employer must maintain a register of workers, which includes particulars such as the worker's name and date of birth, date of appointment, nature of work, and other specified details.
What is the purpose of the Labour Inspector's approval on an establishment's muster-roll or register, according to section (3) of the Act?
The Labour Inspector may approve an establishment's muster-roll or register as its equivalent to the register of workers, if the particulars are already recorded in it.
What is the purpose of issuing a temporary ticket to a temporary worker?
The temporary ticket is issued to ensure that every temporary worker has a record of their worked days, which can be surrendered when they get permanent employment.
How much time does an employer have to issue a leave order after receiving a written application from a worker for leave?
7 days (Section 10(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006)
What happens if a worker's leave is refused or suspended, and how will the fact be communicated to them?

The fact of refusal or postponement and the reasons thereof shall be communicated to the worker before the date on which the leave would have expected to commence, and it shall be recorded in the register maintained for the purpose (Section 10(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006)
What is the procedure if a worker applies for an extension of unavailed leave?

The employer shall send a written reply either granting or refusing the extension of leave to the worker before a reasonable time of the expiry of the leave (Section 11(5) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006)
In what circumstances can an employer stop work in their establishment, and how will they notify the workers?

Fire, sudden catastrophe, breakdown of machinery, stoppage of power supply, epidemics, wide spread riots or any other cause beyond his control. The employer shall notify the concerned workers by a notice posted or hung on the notice board in the section concerned or at a conspicuous place before the next working hour begins (Section 12(2) and (3) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006)
What is the minimum duration for a worker to be entitled to wages if they are directed to stay at their place of work following a stoppage?
1 (one) hour
A worker participates in an illegal strike and the establishment is closed down. What will happen to the worker's wages?
The workers shall not be paid any wages, unless they are entitled to wages under sub-section (5)
What is the calculation method for determining a worker's continuous service in an establishment?

A worker who has actually worked in an establishment for not less than 240 days or 120 days during the preceding 12 calendar months shall be deemed to have completed '1 (one) year' or '6 (six) months' respectively of continuous service
In cases where a worker is laid off due to stoppage of work exceeding 3 working days, what will happen to their wages?
The workers concerned shall be paid wages for all stopped working days exceeding 1 (one) day, and then laid off in accordance with the provisions of section 16
A female worker takes maternity leave not exceeding 16 weeks. How will this duration affect her continuous service calculation?
The days of her maternity leave shall be counted towards her continuous service calculation
What is the minimum number of workers required for an establishment to be exempt from certain provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
5 (five) workers
A worker has completed at least 1 year of service under an employer and is laid-off. What is the basis for calculating their compensation, according to Section 16(2)?
Half of the total of basic wages and dearness allowance and ad-hoc or interim wages
In what circumstances can an employer instead of paying layoff compensation, choose to retrench a worker under Section 20?
If during a calendar year, a worker is laid-off for 15 (fifteen) days or more after the first 45 (forty-five) days, and there is no agreement to the contrary
What is the maximum duration for which a worker can be entitled to payment of compensation under Section 16?
45 (forty-five) days during any calendar year
A substitute worker has completed one year of continuous service in an establishment. How does this affect their status as a substitute for the purpose of Section 16?
They shall not be treated as a substitute for the purpose of Section 16, even if they have completed one year of continuous service
What is the minimum notice period required by an employer before retrenching a worker who has been in continuous service for not less than one year?
1 month’s notice in writing mentioning the reasons for his retrenchment
In case of retrenchment under section 16(7), is notice mentioned in sub-section (2)(a) necessary, and if so, what additional compensation do the worker receive?
No, but the worker shall be paid further 15 days’ wages, in addition to the compensation or gratuity
What happens to a laid-off worker who presents himself for work at the appointed time during normal working hours on any day and is not given employment within 2 hours of his so presenting himself?
He shall be deemed to have been laid-off for that day within the meaning of section (1) (b)
What compensation is payable to a worker who dies while in service for at least more than 02 (two) years continuously under an employer?

30 days wages or, in the case of his death while working in the establishment or in the case of his death following an accident while working in the establishment 45 (forty five) days wages for every completed year of service
In the event of retrenchment on the ground of redundancy, how long should the employer give to a worker who has been in continuous service under an employer for not less than one year?
1 month’s notice in writing mentioning the reasons for his retrenchment
What is the procedure for retrenchment of workers, including notice to be given to the last known address of the retrenched worker?

The employer shall send a notice to the last known address of the retrenched worker asking him to apply for employment, and any worker who applies for re-employment in response to such request shall be given preference. (Section 21)
Under what conditions can a worker be dismissed without a notice or wages in lieu of a notice?
A worker may be dismissed without a notice or without wages in lieu of a notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence; or found guilty of misconduct under section 24. (Section 23(1)(a) and (b))
What is the compensation payable to a discharged worker who completes not less than one year of continuous service?
The employer shall pay the discharged worker, as compensation, 30 (thirty) days' wages for every completed year of his service. (Section 22(2))
What acts are treated as misconduct under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
[List of misconduct acts mentioned in Section 24(4), including willful disobedience, theft, habitual absence without leave, disorderliness, and habitual breach of any law or rule or regulation]
What happens to a worker who is acquitted on an appeal after being dismissed under section 23(1)(a)?

He shall be reinstated to his original post or shall be appointed to a suitable new post; and if any of them is not possible, he shall be paid compensation at a rate equal to the rate of compensation payable to a discharged worker, deducting the amount of compensation already paid to him for his dismissal. (Section 23(5))
What is the minimum period of suspension allowed for a worker charged with misconduct, pending enquiry into the charge?
60 days
Can an employer fine a worker more than one-tenth of their wages payable in a wage-period?
No, no fine exceeding one-tenth of the wages payable to a worker in a wage-period shall be imposed on any worker.
What is the procedure for termination of employment by an employer, other than dismissal, and how much notice must be given to a permanent worker?

The employment of a permanent worker may be terminated by an employer, otherwise than in the manner provided elsewhere in this Chapter, by giving him a notice in writing of 120 days, if he is a monthly rated worker; 60 (sixty) days, in case of other workers.
Can a worker refuse to accept any notice or order from an employer and still be considered to have received it?
Yes, if a copy thereof is exhibited on the notice board and another copy is sent by registered post to the address of the worker obtained from the records of the employer.

What is the criteria for awarding punishment, including the consideration of factors such as previous record, importance of the offence, credit and contribution during service, and any other special circumstances?
The employer shall take into account the previous record of the worker concerned, the importance of the offence, credit and contribution during service, and existing any other special circumstances.
What is the standard notice period required for termination of employment by an employer in case of monthly rated workers?
120 (one hundred twenty) days
A temporary worker resigns his service without giving any notice. According to section 3A, what should the employer do with the worker?
Serve a notice to explain the reason of absence and give the worker further 7 (seven) days time to defend himself
What is the compensation payable to a permanent worker who completes 5-9 years of continuous service, according to section 26(4)?
At the rate of 14 (fourteen) days' wages for every completed year of service
In what age should a worker employed in any establishment retire from employment, as per section 28(1)?
60 (sixty) years of his age
A permanent worker remains absent from his workplace for more than 10 (ten) days without notice or permission. What should the employer do in this situation?
Serve a notice to explain the reason of absence and give the worker further 7 (seven) days time to defend himself, if the worker does not join the service or defend himself
What is the maximum period within which a worker's final payment of dues must be made?
30 (thirty) working days following the date of cessation of employment, as per section 20 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.
In what circumstances can an employer employ a retiring worker under contract, as per section 26(4)?
If it is decided by the authority and in accordance with the service rules of the establishment.
What happens to a worker who does not vacate their residential accommodation within the specified period of 60 days from the date of cessation of employment?

The employer may make a complaint against him to the Labour Court, and if found guilty, may be directed by the Court to vacate the accommodation within a reasonable time, or the police officer may be informed to evict the worker by force.
What is the required procedure for a worker to file a complaint under section 33 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any worker must send their complaint in writing to their employer, by registered post, within 30 (thirty) days of being informed of the cause of such complaint.
What entitlements are reserved for tea industry workers regarding retirement benefits, as per section 26(4)?
Existing retirement benefits, including other benefits, shall be applicable to tea industry workers.
What is the timeframe for an employer to respond to a complaint filed by an employee under Section 2 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Within 30 (thirty) days of receipt of the complaint
Can an employee file an appeal against a decision made by the Labour Court within a specific timeframe?
Yes, within thirty days of the order
What are the conditions under which an adolescent can be employed in any occupation or establishment without restrictions?
If they carry a certificate of fitness issued by a registered medical practitioner and display it while at work
Can an employee file a complaint against an order of termination of employment unless the worker has been deprived of benefits specified under Section 26 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
No, unless the order is alleged to have been made for trade union activities or passed with an ill motive
What happens if a complaint filed by an employee is dismissed without giving any decision under Section 2 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

The employee can submit a new complaint in writing to the Labour Court within thirty days from the date of expiry of the period mentioned in sub-section (2) or from the date of the decision of the employer
What is the basis for determining whether a person is a child or an adolescent?

The age of the concerned person will be resolved on the basis of birth registration certificate, school certificate, or a certificate issued by a registered medical practitioner certifying the age of the concerned person.
What is the purpose of a Certificate of Fitness, and who is responsible for paying its fee?

A Certificate of Fitness is granted to certify an adolescent's fitness for work in any occupation or establishment. The employer is responsible for paying the fee, which shall not be recoverable from the concerned adolescent or their parents/guardians.
What are the working hours restrictions for adolescents in different establishments?

No adolescent shall be allowed to work more than 5 hours in a day and 30 hours in a week in factories or mines, while no adolescent shall be allowed to work more than 7 hours in a day and 42 hours in a week in other establishments.
What are the restrictions on employment of adolescents in hazardous work, and what machines are prohibited for them to work?

No adolescent shall be employed in any work declared by the Government as hazardous. Adolescents shall not clean, lubricate, or adjust machinery while it is in motion or between moving parts/moving and fixed parts of such machinery.
What should an employer do if a Labour Inspector requires them to get an adolescent examined by a medical practitioner due to concerns about the adolescent's fitness?
The employer must comply with the request, get the adolescent examined, and until the adolescent is certified fit or no longer an adolescent, the employer shall not give the adolescent any work.
What is the maximum number of hours an adolescent can work in a week, including overtime, in any factory or mine?
36 hours
An adolescent worker has been assigned to work 2 shifts with each shift exceeding 7.5 hours. Is this allowed under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, according to section (5), the period of any shift shall not exceed more than 7.5 hours
Can an adolescent worker be employed in one relay only, and if so, how often can this be changed with prior permission from the Labour Inspector?
Yes, according to section (6), an adolescent may be employed in one relay only, and this shall not be changed more than once in a period of 30 days
What is the prohibition on employing women workers during the 8 weeks immediately following their delivery, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
(1) No employer shall knowingly engage a woman worker in his establishment during this period; (2) No woman shall work in any establishment during this period
Can a tea plantation worker be employed to do light nature work if she has delivered a child within the preceding 10 weeks, as per section (3) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Yes, provided that the medical practitioner of the concerned tea estate certifies that she is physically fit to do so
According to Section 1 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what is the minimum period of work a woman must have done before being entitled to maternity benefit?
not less than 6 (six) months immediately preceding the day of her delivery
What should an employer do if a pregnant woman does not give notice as required under Section 47(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
inform the concerned woman that she must give notice within 7 (seven) days of giving birth to a child
How many weeks of maternity benefit should be paid to an employer after receiving proof from a registered medical practitioner that the woman is expected to be confined?
within 3 (three) working days following the production of the certificate
If a female worker gives birth to a child before giving notice to her employer, what period should she be allowed to remain absent from work?
8 weeks after the delivery including the whole period of maternity benefits
What happens if a woman fails to produce proof under Section 47(4) within 3 (three) months of her delivery date, according to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
she shall not be entitled to any part of the maternity benefit dependent on the production of such proof
What is the requirement for a woman to be entitled to maternity benefits?
A woman shall not be entitled to maternity benefits, but she can avail leave for health reason.
How long does an employer have to pay maternity benefit in case of death of a woman during the period for which she is entitled to benefit?

If a woman dies during the period for which she is entitled to maternity benefit but before giving birth to a child, the employer shall be liable to pay such benefit for the period preceding and including the day of her death.
What are the restrictions on termination of employment of a woman in certain cases?

If any notice or order of discharge, dismissal, removal or otherwise termination of employment is given by the employer to a woman worker within a period of 6 months before and 8 weeks after her delivery and such notice or order is given without sufficient cause, she shall not be deprived of any maternity benefit to which she would be entitled under this Chapter if such notice or order has not been given.
What are the requirements for a workplace to maintain cleanliness and hygiene?

Every establishment shall be kept clean and free from effluvia arising from any drain, privy or any other nuisance, and in particular, dirt and refuge shall be removed daily by sweeping from the floors, work-rooms, staircases and passages of the establishment.
How often should an employer provide effective means of drainage if a floor becomes wet during manufacturing processes?
Where any floor becomes wet in the course of any manufacturing process to such an extent that drainage is required thereof, effective means of drainage shall be provided and maintained.
What is the minimum number of workers/employees required to arrange a mock firefighting drill in every 6 months?
50 (fifty) workers/employees
Who shall carry out examination or operation on machinery while it's in motion under section 63, and what precautions should be taken?
A specially trained male worker, wearing tight-fitting cloths, and his name shall be recorded in the register prescribed in this behalf.
What is the width limit for a driving belt to rest upon any shaft in motion, as per section 63(1)(b)?
Less than 15 (fifteen) centimetres
Can the cleaning, lubricating, or adjusting of any specified moving part of machinery be prohibited by the Government, and if so, under what provision?
Section 63(2), where the Government may prohibit such activities by notification in the official Gazette.
What is the requirement for suitable devices to cut off power supply from running machinery, as per section 65(2)?
To be provided in every work-room of every establishment.
What is the minimum distance from any fixed structure that a moving part of an automatic machine should not be allowed to move outward or inward in an establishment?
45 centimetres
What conditions must be met for the continued use of a machine installed before the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, which does not comply with section 67 requirements?
Ensuring safety as prescribed by the Inspector General
Who is responsible for thoroughly examining every power driven machinery installed in an establishment at least once in every 12 months, and maintaining a register of such examinations?
A competent person

What additional requirements must be applied to hoists and lifts installed or reconstructed in an establishment after the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, where the cage is dependent on rope or chain?
At least 2 (two) ropes
In what duration should a competent person thoroughly examine hoists and lifts at least once in every 6 months, as per section 69(1)?
Every 6 months
What is the minimum number of ropes or chains required to be connected separately for a cage in an establishment?
At least 2 (two) ropes or chains

In what situation can an Inspector General permit the use of a hoist or lift installed before the commencement of the Act without complying with the provisions of sub-sections (1), (2), (3), (4), and (5)?
Upon such conditions for ensuring safety as he may think fit
What measures shall be taken in respect of every revolving vessel, cage, basket, fly-wheel, pulley disk or similar appliances driven by power to ensure their prescribed speed is not exceeded?
Effective measures shall be taken to ensure that the safe working speed may not be exceeded
Can an employer bring the passages of movements, stairs, gates, godowns and common utility area under close circuit camera for overall safety of the factory and workers?
Yes, as per section (d) of Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006
In what situation is a worker allowed to be in an establishment to lift, carry or move any load so heavy as to be likely to cause his injury?
No worker shall be allowed under any circumstance
What is the requirement for plant or machinery that contains explosive or inflammable gas or vapour under pressure greater than atmospheric pressure?
All practicable measures shall be taken to restrict the spread and effects of the explosion by the provision of chokes, baffles, vents, or any other effective apparatus in the plant or machinery.
What is the procedure for welding or cutting operations that involve explosive or inflammable substances?

Adequate measures must be first taken to remove such substance or fumes or to render them un-flammable or un-explosive, and the substance shall not be allowed to enter the plant, tank, or vessel until the metal is cooled down sufficiently.
What personal safety equipment does an employer need to provide to a worker before engaging them in work?
Personal safety equipments and ensuring uses thereof. A record book shall also be maintained by the employer in the prescribed manner.
In what situation would the Government make special provisions for an establishment under Section 79 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Where the Government is satisfied that any operation carried on in an establishment exposes any person employed in it to a serious risk of bodily injury, poisoning, or disease.
What should be done by an employer if a worker fails to use personal safety equipment supplied?
The worker concerned shall be liable.
What is the time frame for an employer to inform the Labour Inspector of any accident occurring in their establishment?
Within two working days
What is the purpose of registering medical practitioners' reports regarding diseases specified in the Second Schedule?
To inform the Labour Inspector and arrange for treatment of workers suffered or incurred losses from such professional disease
Who has the power to appoint a competent person to hold an enquiry into cases of accident or disease, and what is the purpose of this enquiry?

The Government may appoint a competent person to hold an enquiry into the causes of, and the circumstances appearing in, the accident or disease. The purpose of this enquiry is to determine the necessary actions to be taken
What are the requirements for a notice to be given by an employer regarding certain diseases specified in the Second Schedule?

The notice must include the name and mailing address of the patient, the name of the disease from which the patient is suffering or suspected to be suffering, and the name and address of the establishment where the patient was last employed
What are the obligations of an employer regarding workplace safety and health regulations in Bangladesh?

An employer must provide notice of any corrosive chemicals used in their establishment and take precautions to be taken in their use, as well as inform the Labour Inspector of any accidents or diseases specified in the Second Schedule within the prescribed time frames
What is the timeframe within which an employer can appeal against a labour inspector's order?
Within 10 days of receipt of the order
If an employee informs the employer about a dangerous building or machinery, what is the consequence for the employer if they fail to take appropriate measures?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII
What is the ratio of first-aid box or cupboard to workers that an establishment must provide, as per the Labour Act?
One for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment
In case an employee is injured due to use of a building or machinery that was reported as dangerous, what is the liability of the employer?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII
What is the process for an employer to appeal against a labour inspector's order if they object to it?
The employer must inform the Government in writing, stating their objection and reasons within 20 days of receipt of the order
Who is responsible for maintaining a first-aid treatment facility in an establishment with more than 300 workers?
A person trained in first-aid treatment, available during all working hours of the establishment
What is the minimum number of workers required to have a permanent medical centre in an establishment?
5000 (five thousand) or more workers
How many workers are employed in an establishment where a welfare officer must be appointed?
500 (five hundred) or more workers
What is the minimum number of workers required to have a safety record book and a safety information board in an establishment?
25 (twenty five) workers
A worker suffers from a professional disease after working hours. Who bears the expense and responsibility for the treatment?
The employer until the worker is fully cured of such disease, hurt or sickness
What is the minimum height of a room for children in an establishment where 40 or more female workers are ordinarily employed?
The height of such rooms shall not be less than 360 (three hundred and sixty) centimetres from the floor to the lowest part of the roof.
What provisions must be made in every room for children to ensure sufficient light, air, and ventilation?
Suitable and effective provisions shall be made in every part of each such rooms for sufficient light, air and ventilation of fresh air.
How many square centimetres is the minimum floor area required for each child staying in a room for children?
The floor area for each child staying therein shall be not less than 600 (six hundred) square centimetres.
What should be done to ensure that rooms for children are maintained in clean and sanitary conditions?
The said room shall be maintained in clean and sanitary condition, and shall be under the charge of an experienced or trained woman for the care of children.
How will handicapped workers be prioritized in the allotment of residential accommodation in tea plantations?
The handicapped workers shall be given preference in the allotment of such accommodation.
What is the maximum number of hours an adult worker can work in a day, as per Section 100 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
8 (eight) hours
In what manner should medical care be provided to newspaper workers and their dependents, as per Section 98 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
At the cost of the newspaper establishment in such manner and to such extent as may be prescribed by rules
What is the minimum interval required for rest or meal during working hours, as per Clause (a) of Section 101 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
1 (one) hour

If a central fund is established by the Government in hundred percent export-oriented industrial sector, what will happen to the group insurance requirement for workers in such sectors, as per Section 99(3)?
The workers shall be paid from such fund equal to the money of group insurance
What is the maximum number of hours an adult worker can work in a week, as per Section 102(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
48 (forty-eight) hours
What is the maximum number of hours an adult worker can work in a week, as per Section 108 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
56 (fifty-six) hours
In what circumstances can the Government relax or exempt the provisions of Section 108, as per Subsection (2)?
If it is satisfied that in the public interest or in the interest of economic development such relaxation or exemption is necessary.
What is the entitlement for weekly holidays for workers employed in a road transport establishment, as per Section 103?
One day of twenty-four consecutive hours holiday in a week
Can a worker who has been deprived of their weekly holiday be allowed compensatory holidays, as per Section 104?
Yes, provided that the workers if desire, subject to consultation with the representatives of the collective bargaining agent or participation committee.
What is the maximum number of hours a worker shall work on one vehicle, as per Subsection (b) of Section 107?
1 (one) vehicle
What is the maximum number of establishments an adult worker can work in on the same day, as per section 110 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
1 (one) establishment
What is the requirement for displaying a notice showing the time clearly when adult workers are required to work, as per section 111 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
In every establishment, such notice shall be displayed in accordance with the provisions of section 337 and correctly maintained in the establishment
What is the process for changing the system of work in an establishment, as per sections 10 and 11 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Proposed changes must be sent to the Labour Inspector for approval at least one week before implementation
Who has the authority to approve or modify the notice of hours of work for an establishment, as per section 9 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The Labour Inspector
What is the special age limit requirement for road transport workers, as per sections 112(1) and (2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A driver must have attained the age of 21 years, while a worker in any other post must have attained the age of 18 years
What is the minimum age requirement for a worker to be employed in an establishment?
18 (eighteen) years
According to Section 113 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, what should be done with the working hour of an adult worker?
Correspond with notice and register
What is the provision regarding closure of shops and commercial establishments in Bangladesh?
Every shop or commercial establishment shall remain entirely closed for at least one and a half days in each week, as fixed by the Inspector General
A worker requests casual leave for 15 days, but is only entitled to 10 days of casual leave per year. What should be done?
The employer should deny the request for more than the allowed 10 days of casual leave per year.
What is the provision regarding sick leave for a newspaper worker in Bangladesh?
Newspaper workers are entitled to sick leave with half wages for not less than one-eighteenth of the period of their service.
A worker has completed one year of continuous service in an establishment. What is the entitlement for annual leave with wages?

According to Section 117(1), every adult worker who has completed 1 year of continuous service shall be allowed 12 months' leave with wages, calculated on the basis of the works of the preceding 12 months.
What is the condition for a worker's earned leave to cease?

For an adult worker, earned leave ceases when the earned leave due amounts to 40 days in a factory or road transport establishment, and 60 days in a tea plantation or shop/commercial/industrial establishment (Section 117(5)).
A worker applies for earned leave but is refused by the employer. What happens to the refused leave?
The refused leave shall be added to the credit of such worker beyond the limit mentioned in Section 117(5) or (6). (Section 117(7))
Can a worker's earned leave be accumulated and carried forward to the succeeding years?
No, according to Section 117(4), such leave shall not be accumulated and carried forward to the succeeding years.
What is the entitlement for festival holidays in a calendar year?
Every worker shall be allowed 11 days of festival holiday with wages in a calendar year, as per Section 118(1).
What is the minimum number of festival holidays that a worker shall be allowed in a calendar year, according to Section 118(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
11 days

If an adult worker is entitled to annual leave for a period of not less than 4 days and an adolescent worker for a period of not less than 5 days, at a time, what should be done with the worker's wages before his leave begins?
The worker shall, in so far as it is practicable, be paid his wages for the period of the leave so allowed before his leave begins (Section 119(2))
What happens to a worker's wages if they are not paid by the contractor, but are employed by an establishment where the contractor works?
The wages of such worker shall be paid by the employer of the establishment, and the same shall be adjusted from the contractor (Section 121)
What is the maximum duration of a wage period in respect of payment under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
1 month

If an employee's employment is terminated by retirement, and they have been paid their wages for all but one working day before the expiry of the thirtieth working day following the day of termination, what should be done?
The employer should pay the remaining wage on the next working day (Section 123(3))
According to Section 124(3) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, when should wages be paid?
On the working day following the day of termination of his employment.
What is the purpose of Section 124A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, and what are its key features?

Section 124A allows a worker to apply for wages and other dues to be paid through conciliation. The Inspector General or an authorized officer shall take measures within 52 days to settle the claim through discussion or conciliation meetings.
What types of deductions can be made from a worker's wages, as per Section 125(2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Deductions may be made for: (a) fines imposed under section 25; (b) deductions for unauthorized absence from duty; (c) damage to or loss of goods given under custody; and other approved deductions.
What happens if a worker and employer fail to agree on the conciliator's decision, as per Section 124A(6) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

If both parties do not agree to comply with the conciliator's decision, they may file a suit in the Labour Court for settlement of the issue. The Labour Court shall take into consideration the decision of the conciliator while trying the suit.
What is the requirement for deductions from wages, as per Section 125(2)(d) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Deductions may be made for payment to any co-operative society approved by the Government or to an insurance scheme maintained by the Bangladesh Postal Department.
What is the maximum amount of deduction from wages for absence from duty, as per section 126(2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The amount of such deduction shall, in no case, be more than the amount payable to him for the period of absence.
What is the condition under which deductions from wages can be made for damage or loss caused by a worker's negligence, as per section 127(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any deduction under section 125(2)(c) shall not exceed the amount of the damage or loss caused to the employer by neglect or default of the concerned worker.
Under what conditions can deductions be made from wages for services rendered, as per section 128 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No deduction shall be made from the wages of a worker under section 125(2)(d) and (e) unless the house accommodation, facilities or services provided are accepted by the concerned worker according to the terms of employment.
What is the procedure for deducting amounts for loans or advances given to workers before their employment, as per section 129(a) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Recovery of loan or advance shall be made from the first payment of wages for a complete wage period, but no such deduction shall be made from loan or advance given for traveling expenses.
A worker is absent from work without notice and reasonable cause. According to section 126(2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what happens to their wages?
Wages of not exceeding eight days may also be added to the deduction from wages from every such worker which is payable to the employer in lieu of notice by the terms of his employment.
What happens to a worker's wages if they are not paid due to their death or whereabouts not being known?

The wages shall be paid to the person nominated by the concerned worker, or to the legal heir or heirs of the worker in accordance with the rules. If no nominated person or heir is available, the money shall be deposited into the Workers Welfare Foundation Fund.
How long do I have to file an application to the Labour Court if my wages are deducted or delayed?

You must submit your application within 12 months from the date of deduction of wages or, as the case may be, from the date when the wages became due. However, you may also file an application after this period if you can satisfy the Labour Court that you had sufficient cause for not making the application within such period.
What is the maximum compensation that the Labour Court can direct to be paid in case of delay in payment of wages?

The Labour Court may direct an employer or person responsible for payment of wages to pay 25% (twenty-five per cent) of the wages as compensation to the applicant, subject to certain conditions and if the Labour Court is satisfied that the delay was due to a bonafide error or dispute.
Can I be fined by the Labour Court for filing an application under section 132(1) if it is deemed malicious or vexatious?

Yes, the Labour Court may impose a fine of not exceeding taka 200 (two hundred) on the applicant if they are found to have filed an application under section 132(1) that is deemed malicious or vexatious.
What should I do with the money deposited into the Workers Welfare Foundation Fund if my nominated person or heir is not available within 12 months?
If your nominated person or heir is not available within 12 months, the money shall be considered to be the property of the Bangladesh Workers Welfare Foundation.
What is the procedure for attaching property to secure payment of wages under Section 121?
The Court or Tribunal may attach property to secure payment of wages under Section 121, after giving the employer an opportunity of being heard.
Who can recover money ordered to be paid by a Labour Court or Tribunal if it is unable to recover from other responsible persons?
The employer can recover money ordered to be paid by a Labour Court or Tribunal if it is unable to recover from other responsible persons.
How are the members of the Minimum Wages Board appointed?

The Chairman and independent member of the Wage Board are appointed from among persons with adequate knowledge of industrial labour and economic conditions, while the member representing employers and workers is appointed after considering nominations from representative organizations.
What is the process for recommending minimum rates of wages for certain workers?
The Government may direct the Wage Board to recommend minimum rates of wages after necessary enquiry, based on prevailing wage rates in the industry.
In case no nominations are received from representative organizations despite multiple efforts, what happens?
The Government may appoint persons whom it considers fit to be representative of employers or workers if no nominations are received.
What is the timeframe for the Wage Board to submit its recommendation to the Government for fixing minimum rates of wages?
Within 6 (six) months of receipt of such direction
Can the Government extend the period for the Wage Board to submit its recommendation, and if so, under what conditions?
Yes, the Government may extend the period on the request of the Wage Board.
What is the basis on which the minimum rates of wages recommended by the Wage Board can be modified or changed by the Government?
The Government may modify or change the recommendation made by the Wage Board, subject to such modifications and exceptions as may be specified in a notification.
What is the period after which the minimum rates of wages fixed for workers employed in any industry shall be re-fixed, and on whose direction?
Every 5 (five) years on the direction by the Government
Can a court or authority question the minimum rates of wages declared under this section, and what is the consequence if no objection is raised?
No, the minimum rates of wages declared under this section shall be final and shall not, in any manner, be questioned.
What is the effect of declaring minimum wages under section 140 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The declared minimum rates of wages shall be final and not questioned in any Court or before any authority.
How often should the Wages Board review its recommendations for minimum wages, as per section 142(1)?
The Wages Board shall review its recommendations once again within a period of either 1 year or 3 years from the date on which it was made.
What factors should the Wages Board consider when making recommendations for minimum wages, as per section 141?

The Wages Board shall take into account the cost of living, standard of living, cost of production, productivity, price of products, inflation, nature of work, risk and standard, business capability, socio-economic conditions of the country and the locality concerned, and other relevant factors.
What should happen to the decision of the Newspaper Wages Board, as per section 145(1)?
The Government shall examine the decision within a period of 3 months from its receipt and publish it by notification in the official Gazette with necessary modifications.
What is the requirement for the establishment of a separate Wage Board, as per section 143(1)?

The Government may establish a separate Wage Board if it thinks fit by notification in the official Gazette, comprising a Chairman and equal numbers of members representing both employers and newspaper workers appointed by the Government.
What is the effective date of interim rates of wages fixed by the Newspaper Wages Board, as per section 146(2)?
The effective date of interim rates of wages shall be specified in the notification or will come into force on the date of its publication if no specific date is mentioned.
What are the circumstances under which an employer shall not be liable to pay compensation for injury caused by an accident, as per section 150(2)?

[a] The worker does not lose the ability to work, in whole or in part, for a period exceeding three days due to injury; [b] The cause of injury is not resulting in death and is directly attributed to (i) the worker having been at that time under the influence of drink or drugs; (ii) willful disobedience by the worker of a clear order or rules made for securing the safety of workers; or (iii) willful removal or disregard by the worker of any safety guard or other device known to have been provided for securing the safety of workers.
What is the minimum rate of wage that shall be binding on all employers and every worker, as per section 148?

The minimum rates of wage declared under section 140 or published under section 145 shall be binding on all employers concerned and every worker shall be entitled to be paid wages at the rate not less than the rates so declared or published.
What is the maximum period for which a worker can continue to receive wages at a higher rate than the minimum rates, as per section 149(2)?

Nothing in sub-section (1) shall prejudice, in any way, the right of a worker to continue to receive wages at a rate higher than the minimum rates declared or published under this Chapter or other facilities.

In case of a dispute arising as to classification or re-classification of a newspaper or newspaper establishment due to the decision of the Newspaper Wages Board, what is the option for an aggrieved person?
Any person aggrieved by such decision may apply to the Labour Court for adjudication of the dispute.
What is the method of calculating wages under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
For the purposes of this Chapter, 'monthly wages' means the amount of wages deemed to be payable for work of 1 month, whether the wages is payable by month or by other period or at piece rates.
How is the monthly wage of a worker calculated if they were in the service of the employer for less than 12 months immediately preceding the accident?

The monthly wage shall be the sum equal to the monthly average of income which, during the 12 (twelve) months immediately preceding the accident, was being earned by a worker employed on the same work by the same employer, or, if there was no worker so employed, by any other worker employed on similar work in the same locality.
What is the basis for calculating monthly wages if the worker has been absent from work for exceeding 14 (fourteen) days?
Any period of service shall be deemed to be continuous which is not interrupted by a period of absence from work for exceeding 14 (fourteen) days.
Can an employer or worker request a review of monthly compensation payable under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Yes, any monthly compensation payable under this Chapter may be reviewed by the Labour Court if an application is made either by the employer or by the worker accompanied by a certificate.
What happens to monthly compensation if the disablement ceases before the date on which any monthly compensation is payable?
A sum proportionate to the duration of the disablement in that month shall be payable in respect of that month.
What is the procedure for applying for a review of the compensation payable to a worker under Section 63 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
An application can be made either by the employer or by the worker, accompanied by a certificate from a registered medical practitioner stating that the condition of the worker has changed
Can an employer pay monthly compensation payable to a worker in lump sum amount on the basis of an agreement between the parties, as per Section 154 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Yes, an employer may pay monthly compensation payable to a worker by paying a lump-sum amount on the basis of the agreement between the parties
What happens to the monthly compensation payable to a worker if it is found that permanent disablement results from the accident, as per Section 64 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The monthly compensation payable may be converted to a lump sum to which the worker is entitled
Can an employer make advance payment as compensation to any of his dependents in case of a deceased worker, as per Section 155(3) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Yes, an employer may make advance payment as compensation to any of his dependents
What is the procedure for distributing compensation payable to a deceased worker, as per Section 155(1) and (5) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

The compensation shall be deposited with the Labour Court on behalf of the person entitled thereto, and a receipt given by the Labour Court is a sufficient discharge in respect of any compensation deposited
What is the purpose of the fund established by the Government under Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The fund is established to transfer undistributed money deposited with it for the welfare of workers.
How will the Labour Court distribute compensation paid to a dependent in case of a deceased worker's death, as per Section (9) of the Act?
The Labour Court may apportion the compensation among the dependents of the deceased worker or allot it to any one dependent in such proportion as they think fit.
What is the maximum period within which a claim for compensation must be preferred before it can be considered by the Labour Court, as per Section (2) of the Act?
The claim must be preferred within 2 (two) years of the occurrence of the accident or within 2 (two) years of the date of death.
Can a dependent's claim for compensation be set off against any other claim, and what is the reason behind this prohibition as per Section (156) of the Act?
No, a dependent's claim cannot be set off against any other claim. This is because the Act prohibits assigning, attaching, or charging compensation to any person other than the worker.
What should be done by the Labour Court in case it varies an order under Section (13) of the Act due to negligence of a parent to heir their children, as per Section (14) of the Act?

The Labour Court may make such order for the variation of its former order as they think fit in the circumstances of the case, provided that such person has been given an opportunity of showing cause against the order.
What is the applicable date for determining an accident in case of disablement caused by a disease?
The first day of the continuous absence of the worker
Can a Labour Court consider and decide a claim to compensation if the notice is not given or the claim is not preferred on time?
Yes, if the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient reason for the failure to give such notice or prefer such claim (Section 4)
How should a notice under Section 150 be served, and what information must it contain?

It shall be served by delivering it at, or sending it by registered post addressed to, the residence or office of the person on whom it is to be served; it must state the name and address of the injured worker, cause of injury, and date of accident
What is the deadline for an employer to submit a statement regarding a fatal accident, as required by Section 158?
Within 30 days of receiving the notice
What happens if an employer disputes liability for compensation in case of a fatal accident?
The Labour Court may inform dependents of the deceased worker that it is open to them to prefer a claim for compensation and provide them with such information as the Court thinks fit (Section 4)
What is the timeframe for an employer to cause a worker to be examined at the expense of the employer by a registered medical practitioner after receiving notice of an accident?
Within 3 (three) days of service of such notice
In case of grave nature, where should the employer cause the worker to be examined?
At the place where the worker is staying
What happens to a worker's right to compensation if they refuse to present themselves for medical examination or obstruct it?
Their right to compensation remains suspended during the continuance of such refusal or obstruction, unless prevented by sufficient cause.
If an injured worker refuses to accept offered medical treatment and deliberately disregards instructions, what happens to their compensation?

The injury and disablement evident from it shall be deemed to be of the same nature and duration as they might have reasonably been expected if the worker had been regularly attended by a registered medical practitioner and followed his instructions.
What is the consequence of an injured worker who dies without having present themselves for medical examination?
The Labour Court may direct for the payment of compensation to the dependents of the deceased worker
According to Section 161(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, what happens when an employer contracts with a contracting agency for work execution?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to any worker employed by the contractor as if they were directly employed by the employer.
If an employee dies due to injury caused by the negligence of a contractor, who will bear the expenses of re-examination of the medical report?
The employer or the worker, whichever is applicable, shall bear the expenses incurred for such examination
What happens to the right of the employer against an insurer in case of insolvency, as per Section 162(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The right of the employer is transferred to and vests in the worker.
According to Section 11 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, what type of insurance scheme can an establishment with at least 10 workers introduce?
A group insurance programme against accidents under which benefits or money received shall be spent for the treatment of workers.
If a worker claims compensation from the employer but receives lower wages from the contractor, what option does the worker have in the insolvency or liquidation proceedings?
The worker may prove it in the insolvency or liquidation proceedings to ensure they receive the higher amount
What is the amount of compensation that a worker can claim in case of an accident, and how long does the employer have to pay it?

According to Section 163(3), the claim for compensation shall be made within 6 months after the news of the death is received by the claimant. However, where the ship is or is deemed to have been lost with all its crew, the claim must be made within 18 months.
In case of insolvency or liquidation proceedings, what happens to the amount paid to a worker?

According to Section 163(1), if an insurer is void or voidable by reason of non-compliance with any terms and conditions of the contract (other than payment of premium), the provisions of Sub-section (4) shall apply as if the contract were not void or voidable, and the insurer shall be entitled to prove in insolvency or liquidation proceedings the amount paid to the worker.
Can a seaman give notice of an accident even if it occurred on board the ship?
No, according to Section 163(2), where the accident occurred and the disablement commenced on board the ship, it shall not be necessary for any seaman to give any notice of the accident.
How long does an employer have to pay compensation to a master or seaman in case of death?

According to Section 163(3), the claim for compensation shall be made within 6 months after the news of the death is received by the claimant. Where the ship is or is deemed to have been lost with all its crew, the claim must be made within 18 months.
Can a foreign country's deposition taken by a Judge or Magistrate be used as evidence in proceedings for enforcing any claim?

Yes, according to Section 163(4), where the injured master or seaman is discharged or left behind in a foreign country, any deposition taken by any Judge or Magistrate of that country or by any Consular Officer in that country and transmitted to the Government by him shall be admissible in evidence in proceedings for enforcing any claim if it meets certain conditions.
What is the requirement for a deposition to be considered sufficient evidence of an opportunity to cross-examine witnesses?
Unless the contrary is proved, it shall be sufficient if taken in a criminal proceeding and the person accused was present
Under what circumstances is compensation not payable under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

[No monthly payment as compensation shall be payable in respect of the period during which the owner of the ship is, under any law for the time being in force relating to merchant shipping, liable to defray the expenses of maintenance of the injured master and seaman]
What happens if an application for payment of compensation under a scheme referred to in section (6) is made within one month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given?
Proceedings under this Chapter may be commenced within 1 month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given
What is the effect of an agreement made before or after the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, whereby a worker relinquishes any right to compensation?
Such agreement shall be void to such extent as to remove or reduce the liability of any person to pay compensation under this Chapter
What is the purpose of a return that must be sent by every person employing workers, as directed by the Government?
To send a correct return specifying the number of injuries in respect of which compensation was paid by the employer during the previous year and the amount of such compensation
What is the procedure for registering an agreement under Section 170 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A memorandum of such an agreement must be sent to the Labour Court by the employer, and the Court shall record it in a register if satisfied with its genuineness.
In case of a fatal accident, what is the power of the Labour Court to require more deposit from the employer?

The Labour Court may call upon the employer to show cause as to why they should not make a further deposit within a specified time, and if they fail, the Court may determine compensation and require the employer to deposit the deficiency.
What is the condition under which an application for settlement of any matter by a Labour Court can be made?

No application can be made unless both parties have failed to settle the question raised as to such matter by agreement, except in cases where the worker himself suffers losses or a dependent makes the application.
What is the venue of proceedings for matters under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The same shall be done by or before the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the accident took place, unless the worker is a master of a ship or a seaman, in which case it shall be done by or before the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the owner or agent resides or carries on business.
Can a civil court have jurisdiction to settle any question required to be settled by a Labour Court under Section 166 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, no civil Court shall have jurisdiction to settle any question which is by or under this Chapter required to be settled by the Labour Court.
What happens if an agreement for payment of compensation is not registered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The employer shall be liable to pay the full amount of compensation payable by him under this Chapter, and he shall not be entitled to deduct more than half of any amount paid to the worker by way of compensation.
What is the requirement for an appeal to lie against an order of a Labour Court under Section 172(1)(a)?
A substantial question of law must be involved in the appeal, and the amount in dispute in the appeal must not be less than 1,000 (one thousand) taka.
What is the period of limitation for an appeal under Section 172(5)?
The period of limitation for an appeal under this section shall be 60 (sixty) days.
In what circumstances can a Labour Court withhold payment of any sum deposited with it, as per Section 173?
Where the employer prefers an appeal under Section 172(1)(a), and if the Tribunal so directs, it shall surely be withheld.
What is the condition for transferring money deposited with a Labour Court to another country, as per Section 174?
No sum deposited under this Chapter in respect of any fatal accident shall be transferred without the consent of the employer.
What is required to be included in a trade union's constitution for registration under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The name and address of the trade union, the purpose of its formation, the procedure for becoming a member, the sources of its fund, and the purposes for which such fund shall be utilized.
How long can the term of office of officers in a group of establishments be?
Not more than 3 (three) years.
What is the procedure for dissolution of a trade union as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The manner of dissolution is not specified, but it can be done through a resolution passed by the general members or by the Central Committee.
In what form should a declaration of obtaining membership be made in accordance with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Prescribed Form.
What are the conditions under which a member of a trade union shall be entitled to any benefit assured by its constitution, and how can any fine or forfeiture be imposed on a member?
The conditions for entitlement to benefits and the imposition of fines or forfeitures are specified in the constitution of the trade union.
What is the minimum membership required for a trade union to be entitled to registration under the labour act?
20% of the total number of workers employed in the establishment in which it is formed
How long must an officer or member of a trade union wait after being convicted of a criminal offence before they can be disqualified from election?
A period of 2 years has elapsed since his release
In what cases may members of a nationalized industrial sector union elect officials not working in the concerned establishment?
If they desire, ten percent (10%) of the total officials of the executive committee
What is the maximum number of trade unions that can be registered at any time in an establishment or group of establishments?
No more than 3 (three) trade unions
Under what circumstances may a dispute regarding whether two or more establishments are under the same employer be referred to the Director General for settlement?

When there is doubt or dispute as to whether two or more establishments are under the same employer, or whether they are allied to and connected with one another for the purpose of carrying out the same industry
What is the time limit for the Director General to register a trade union after receiving an application?
Within 55 (fifty five) days from the date of receipt of the application
A trade union has applied for registration but the Director General finds it deficient in material respect. How long does the trade union have to reply to the objection?
Within a period of 15 (fifteen) days from the receipt of the objection
What is considered a 'group of establishments' for the purpose of forming a trade union under Section 183?
All establishments in a specified area carrying on the same specified industry where more than 20 (twenty) workers are employed
A trade union has applied for registration but the Director General rejects it. What is the next step for the trade union?
The trade union can prefer an appeal to the Labour Court within 30 (thirty) days from the date of rejection or the expiry of the 55-day period, whichever is earlier
What is the purpose of a Standard Operating Procedure in keeping with Section 183, as mentioned in Section 187?
To settle applications for registration of trade unions
What is the maximum number of workers allowed in a small-scale metal industry for registration with the labour department?

Not specified, but industries such as tea industry, jute bailing, tannery industry, bidi, handloom, hosiery, printing press, and hotels/motels with 25 guest rooms or less are exempt from this requirement.
Can a worker employed in an establishment included in a group of establishments be elected as an officer of the trade union formed by the workers in that group?
Yes, but only if the constitution of the trade union provides for it. The number of such persons shall not exceed one-fourth of the total number of officers in the union.
How many percent of workers must be employed in all establishments included in a group of establishments for a trade union to be registered?
At least 30% of the total number of workers employed in all establishments included in such group.
Can Bangladeshian seamen form their own trade union, and if so, what requirements must they meet?
Yes. No seaman shall be a member unless he has a continuous discharge certificate or an appointment letter showing his employment as a seaman in any establishment of merchant shipping business.
How many trade unions can be formed by workers employed in the Chittagong Port Authority and Mongla Port Authority?
Only one. The employees may form their own trade union, subject to certain provisions.
What is the period required for a worker to be employed in any port user, berth operator, ship handling operator and other establishments related to the port before they can join a trade union?
More than 1 (one) year
Who has prior permission of the Director General to alter the terms and conditions of service of any officer of a trade union without the employer's consent?
The Director General
What is the timeframe for existing trade unions formed for employers of workers and employees to be dissolved upon the formation of a new trade union under Section 5?
Within 6 (six) months
Can an employer terminate the employment of any worker who is a member of a trade union while an application for registration is pending, according to Section 26?
No, as per Section 2
How should employers inform the Director General about changes in the constitution and executive committee of a trade union, and what is the timeframe for such notification?
Within 15 (fifteen) days by registered post or hand delivery
What is the timeframe for the Director General to cancel the registration of a trade union?
30 (thirty) days from the date of receipt of permission from the Labour Court
Who can appeal against the decision of the Labour Court granting permission to cancel the registration of a trade union?
Any person aggrieved by the order of the Labour Court
What is the condition for cancelling the registration of a trade union on the ground mentioned in sub-section (1) (e)?
An application must be submitted to the Labour Court within 3 (three) months of the occurrence of unfair labour practice by such trade union
What is the consequence if a trade union does not function as a registered trade union?
It shall not function as a trade union, and no person shall collect any subscription for the fund of the trade union except enrollment fee for membership
Can a worker or employer be a member of more than one trade union at the same establishment?
No, workers and employers are entitled to enroll themselves as members of only one trade union at a time at the same establishment
What is the name of the body corporate that a trade union shall be, and what rights does it have?

A trade union shall be a body corporate by the name under which it is registered, and it shall have perpetual succession and a common seal, and shall have power to enter into contract and to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable.
Is an employer allowed to impose any condition in a contract of employment that restricts a worker's right to join or continue membership of a trade union?
