No, an employer shall not impose any condition in a contract of employment restraining the right of the worker concerned to join a trade union or continue his membership of a trade union.

What is the consequence for an employer who discriminates against a worker in regard to any employment, promotion, conditions of employment, or working conditions on the ground that such worker is, or is not, a member or officer of a trade union?
The employer shall be liable for unfair labour practice.
Can an employer transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in contravention of section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, an employer shall not transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in contravention of the provisions of section 187.
What is the standard procedure that the Government shall frame to enquire into unfair labour practice?
The Government shall frame Standard Operating Procedure in keeping with the provision of this section.
What activities are exempt from prohibition under Section 82(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof.
What is considered an unfair practice for a trade union to interfere in the election held under Section 202 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Intimidation, undue impersonation, or bribery through the officer of that trade union or any other person acting on its behalf.
What is anti-trade union discrimination as defined in Section 196A(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Discrimination by employers against workers during the process of trade union formation or registration, or during pendency of an application for registration.
Can a trade union compel or attempt to compel a worker to pay or refrain from paying subscription fees to the fund of the trade union?

No, under Section 82(3)(e) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, a trade union cannot use intimidation, coercion, pressure, threat, confinement, physical injury, disconnection of telephone, water, or power facilities, or any other means to compel a worker to pay or refrain from paying subscription fees.
What is the standard operating procedure for enquiring into unfair labour practice as per Section 196A(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The Government shall frame a Standard Operating Procedure in keeping with the provisions of this section.
Who can be held liable for a tortuous act done in contemplation or furtherance of an industrial dispute by an agent of a trade union?
An agent of the trade union, if it is proved that such agent acted without the knowledge of or contrary to the clear instructions of the executive committee of the trade union.
What is required for a trade union to join in a federation of trade unions?
Five or more trade unions formed in establishments engaged in or carrying on the same or identical industry, and the trade union organizations of more than one administrative division
How must an application for the registration of a federation of trade unions be signed?
By the Chairman and General Secretary of all the trade unions constituting the federation, accompanied by three copies of the deed of federation.
What is the minimum number of national-based trade union federations required to constitute a national-level confederation?
At least ten
Can a trade union of workers join in a federation with a trade union of employers, or vice versa?
No, a trade union of workers shall not join in a federation of trade unions of employers and a trade union of employers shall not join in a federation of trade unions of workers.
What is the deadline for a registered trade union to submit its general statement to the Director General, as per Section 3 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
within 30 (thirty) days of the receipt of such notice

How many trade unions must be members of a federation in order for the federation's name to be included in the general statement submitted by the trade union, as per Section 4 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
not specified
How many workers must be members of a trade union in order for that union to be declared the CBA for an establishment, as per Section 5(5) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
not less than one-third of the total number of workers employed in the establishment

messages.content: What is the condition under which a federation of trade unions can act as the collective bargaining agent in an establishment?

A federation of trade unions shall be deemed to be the collective bargaining agent in any establishment or group of establishments, if any of its federated unions in that establishment authorizes it to act as the collective bargaining agent on its behalf.
How much wage deduction is permissible from an employee's wages for subscription to a CBA union, with the approval of each individual worker?

An employer shall deduct such amounts towards the subscriptions to the fund of the CBA union as may be specified, with the approval of each individual worker named in the demand statement furnished by the CBA union.
What is the procedure for establishing a participation committee in an establishment where at least 50 workers are ordinarily employed?

The employer shall constitute a participatory committee in his establishment through direct involvement of the workers working in that establishment, in accordance with the prescribed manner by rules.
What happens to the worker representatives of a participation committee if no trade union exists in an establishment where they are elected?
They may carry out the activities related to the interests of the workers until a trade union is formed in that establishment.
Can an employer transfer or remove a participatory committee member without their consent, and what are the implications if they do?

An employer shall not transfer or remove an elected or nominated officer or a member of the participatory committee belonging to the workers' side during the tenure of the committee without his consent. Retaliatory measures against such workers may be considered.
What is the main function of a participation committee under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The main function of a participation committee is to inculcate and develop a sense of belonging among workers and employers, and to ensure the application of labour laws, foster a sense of discipline, improve safety, occupational health, and working conditions, encourage vocational training, workers' education, and family welfare training, adopt measures for improvement of welfare services, and target productivity.
What happens if an employer or collective bargaining agent finds that an industrial dispute is likely to arise between the employer and the workers?

The employer or collective bargaining agent shall communicate their views in writing to the other party within 15 days of receipt, and the parties shall arrange a meeting with it for discussion and consultation.
Can an industrial dispute be deemed to exist unless it is raised by an employer or a collective bargaining agent?

Yes, no industrial dispute shall be deemed to exist unless it is raised by an employer or a collective bargaining agent in accordance with the provisions of Chapter XIV of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.
How often must the participation committee meet to discuss and exchange views and recommend measures for performance of its functions?
The participation committee shall meet at least once every 2 (two) months to discuss and exchange views and recommend measures for performance of its functions under section 206.
What happens if an employer or the trade union finds difficulties in implementing the recommendations of the participation committee within the specified time?
The employer or the trade union shall inform the committee about it and make all possible efforts to implement the same as early as possible, within the period specified by the committee.
What is the timeframe for a party to respond to a communication under subsection (1) of the Labour Act, and what happens if they fail to do so?

Within 15 days of receiving the communication. If the party fails to arrange a meeting with the other party within this time, or no settlement is reached within a period of one month from the date of the first meeting, they may report the matter to a competent Conciliator.
What is the role of the Conciliator in resolving disputes between employers and employees, and how long does it take for them to start conciliation?
The Conciliator shall try to persuade the parties to agree on a settlement within a reasonable period. The Conciliator starts conciliation within 10 days of receipt of a request.
What is the process for referring a dispute to an Arbitrator, and what happens if the parties fail to agree on an Arbitrator?

If the parties agree to refer the dispute to an Arbitrator, they shall make a joint request in writing. If the parties do not agree to refer the dispute to an Arbitrator within 3 days of failure of conciliation, the Conciliator issues a certificate stating that it has failed.
How long does an Arbitrator have to give their award after receiving a request for arbitration, and what happens if they fail to do so?

Within 30 days from the date of receipt of the request or within such further period as may be agreed upon in writing by the parties. If the Conciliator determines that an Arbitrator's award is required but no agreement can be reached, they shall notify the Government.
What is the requirement for a memorandum of settlement to be recorded in writing and signed by both parties, and what happens if it is not done?

A copy of the memorandum of settlement shall be forwarded by the employer to the Government, the Director General, and the Conciliator. Failure to do so may result in further conciliation or arbitration being pursued.
What is the duration of an award issued by the Labour Court, and can it be extended?
An award of the Labour Court shall remain in force for a period specified in the award, which shall not be more than 2 (two) years. (Section 7)
What happens to an industrial dispute if one party fails to make a request to conciliate or commence strike/lock-out within the specified time?

If the party raising an industrial dispute under section 210 fails to make a request to conciliate, commence strike/lock-out on the date specified in the notice, or refer the dispute to the Labour Court for settlement, the dispute shall cease to exist on the expiry of such specified time or date. (Section 212(1))
How long can an industrial dispute be prohibited in a new establishment owned by foreigners or established in collaboration with foreigners?

An industrial dispute shall be prohibited in an establishment for a period of 3 (three) years from the date of commencement of production therein, if such establishment is a new one or is owned by foreigners or is established in collaboration with foreigners. (Section 8)
What are the terms and conditions for the appointment of members of a Labour Court?

The Chairman of a Labour Court shall be appointed by the Government from amongst the District Judges or Additional District Judges who are in service, while the terms and conditions of appointment of the Chairman and members of a Labour Court shall be determined by the Government. (Section 5)
Can a worker raise a new industrial dispute within one year of an existing dispute being settled?
No fresh dispute on the same subject shall be raised within a period of one year from the date of cessation of such dispute. (Section 212(2))
What is the procedure for selecting representatives to a Labour Court for hearing industrial disputes?
The Chairman of a Labour Court shall select one representative from each of the two panels mentioned in sub-section (7), unless otherwise specified by the Chairman.
Can a member of a Labour Court be absent or unable to attend without affecting the proceedings and decision of the Court?
No, if any member of a Labour Court is absent or unable to attend, the proceedings may begin or continue in their absence, and the decision or award of the Court may be given in their absence.
What are the exclusive jurisdiction matters of a Labour Court?

content: to adjudicate and determine any industrial dispute or any other dispute or question referred to or brought or made before it under this Act;
to enquire into, adjudicate and determine any matter relating to the implementation or violation of a settlement referred to by the Government;
to try offences under this Act;
to exercise and perform such other powers and functions as are or may be conferred upon or assigned to by or under this Act or any other law.

messages.content: Can a Labour Court impose penalties on an employer for violating labour laws?
Yes, a Labour Court shall have the same power to impose penalties as is vested in a Court of Sessions under the Code of Criminal Procedure.
What are the powers and procedure of a Labour Court when dealing with matters other than trial of offences?

content: to adjudicate and determine any matter, question or dispute, be deemed to be a civil Court and have the same powers as are vested in such Court under the Code of Civil Procedure;
to enforce the attendance of any person, examine him on oath and take evidence

messages.content: What is the maximum time period allowed for a party to file a written statement or objection in response to a notice from the Labour Court?
10 days
In the event of failure to comply with the Labour Court's order, what happens if both parties pray for adjournment?
The hearing may be adjourned for not exceeding 10 (ten) days in all.
What is the consequence if a party filing a case is absent on the date of hearing?
The case shall be dismissed for default, unless the Court has power to set aside the order of dismissal within 3 (three) months from the date of such order.
What is the general rule regarding the delivery of judgment, decision, or an award by a Labour Court?
The judgment, decision, or an award shall be delivered in writing and delivered in open Court within 60 (sixty) days from the date of filing of the case.
What is the procedure for withdrawing a case from the Labour Court after it has been filed?
An application to withdraw the case may be made by all parties to the court, which shall be heard and allowed if the dispute has been amicably settled.
Who can appoint the Chairman and members of the Labour Appellate Tribunal?
The Government, by notification in the official Gazette
What is the maximum time limit for the Tribunal to deliver its judgment?
60 (sixty) days from the date of preferring an appeal, with an option to extend it to 90 (ninety) days with recording reasons
In case of a disagreement among the members of a bench in the Tribunal, what happens next?
The matter is decided according to the opinion of the majority of members, and if they are equally divided, it is referred to the Chairman for hearing on such point
Can an employee appeal against a judgment or decision made by the Labour Court?
Yes, the Tribunal may confirm, vary, modify, or set aside any judgment, decision, award, or sentence of a Labour Court
What is the punishment for contempt of the Tribunal or a Labour Court?
The same as if it were the High Court Division of the Supreme Court
What is the procedure for filing an application or appeal with a Labour Court or Tribunal?

An application to a Labour Court or an appeal to the Tribunal shall be made in such form, as may be prescribed by rules, and shall contain, in addition to such particulars as may be prescribed by rules, the names and addresses of the parties, a concise statement of the circumstances of the application or appeal, and the relief claimed.
Who is responsible for paying costs in a case before a Labour Court or Tribunal?
All costs incidental to any case or appeal before a Labour Court or Tribunal shall be awardable at the discretion of such Court or Tribunal.
What is the condition for a settlement arrived at by an agreement between an employer and a trade union to be binding?
A settlement arrived at by an agreement between the employer and a trade union of the workers of his establishment, otherwise than by conciliation, shall be binding on the parties to the agreement.
What is the requirement for an application under Chapter X to be considered valid?

In any case other than an application by dependents for payment of compensation under Chapter XII, a concise statement showing separately the basic wages, dearness allowance, ad-hoc or interim wages, and other sums payable with wages payable to the applicant per month must be included.
What is the jurisdiction of the Labour Court to entertain an application?
A statement showing that the Labour Court has jurisdiction to entertain the application must be included in the application.
What is the duration of a settlement in Bangladesh, as per Section 223(2) of the Labour Act 2006?
A settlement remains effective for a period of 1 (one) year from the date of signing the memorandum of settlement by the parties.
If a party wishes to terminate an award, how long does it need to inform the other party in writing before it ceases to be binding?

An award continues to be binding on the parties until either party informs the other party in writing of its intention not to be bound any longer by the award within 2 (two) months from the date of expiry.
What is the effect of a Labour Court's decision in an appeal, as per Section 223(7) of the Labour Act 2006?
A decision of the Tribunal in an appeal in respect of an award shall be effective from the date of the award.
In what circumstances can a party apply to the Labour Court for reduction of the period mentioned in sub-section (4) or (5), as per Section 223(6) of the Labour Act 2006?
A party can apply to the Labour Court if the circumstances in which the award was made have materially changed before the expiry of the period mentioned in sub-section (4) or (5).
When can an industrial dispute be raised again, as per Section 223(9) of the Labour Act 2006?

No industrial dispute or proceedings in respect thereof shall be raised or commenced again before the expiry of 1 (one) year from the date of signing of the memorandum of settlement by the parties to the dispute or the date of expiry of the period of settlement or award, whichever is later.
What is the procedure for serving a notice of strike or lock-out in an industrial dispute?

No notice of strike or lock-out shall be served by any party to an industrial dispute during the continuance ofconciliation in any matter relating to the industrial dispute or a case in this behalf is pending before a Labour Court or an appeal is pending before the Tribunal.
Under what circumstances can a Labour Court or Tribunal prohibit the continuation of a strike or lock-out?

[Section 226(1)] Where a strike or lock-out in pursuance of an industrial dispute has already commenced, and such strike or lock-out continues at the time of submitting an application to the Labour Court in relation to that industrial dispute, or when it is under consideration of the Labour Court.
What are the grounds for which a strike or lock-out will be considered illegal?

[Section 227(1)(a)-(d)] A strike or lock-out shall be illegal if: (i) it is declared, commenced or continued without giving to the other party to the dispute a notice of strike or lock-out in the manner prescribed by rules; (ii) it is declared, commenced or continued in consequence of an industrial dispute raised in a manner other than that provided in section 209; (iii) it is continued in contravention of an order made under section 211 or 226; or (iv) it is declared, commenced or continued during the period in which a settlement or award is in operation in respect of the matter covered by such settlement or award.
What protection is afforded to workers involved in industrial disputes regarding changes to their terms and conditions of service?

[Section 228(1)] An employer shall not, during the continuance of anyconciliation proceeding or proceedings before an Arbitrator, Labour Court or Tribunal in any matter relating to an industrial dispute, alter to the disadvantage of any worker who is involved in such dispute the conditions of service applicable to him before the commencement of such proceedings.

Can an officer of a trade union be discharged, dismissed, or otherwise punished for misconduct during the pendency of any proceedings referred to in Section 228(1), without permission from the Labour Court?

[Section 228(2)] Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), an officer of a trade union shall not, during the pendency of any proceedings referred to in the said sub-section, be discharged, dismissed or otherwise punished for misconduct, except with the previous permission of the Labour Court.
What is the minimum paid-up capital required for a company to be eligible for the provisions of Chapter XV, as per Section 232(1)(a) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
taka 1 (one) crore
A worker is expelled from a trade union due to his refusal to participate in an unfair labour practice. Can he be subject to expulsion from any other trade union and liable to fines or penalties?

No, he shall not be subject to expulsion from any trade union, or to any fine or penalty, or he or his legal representative shall not be deprived of any right or benefit which he would otherwise have been entitled to.
In an industrial dispute, what is the entitlement of a worker and employer in terms of representation in proceedings before the Labour Court?

A worker who is a party to an industrial dispute shall be entitled to be represented in any proceedings under this Chapter by an officer of a collective bargaining agent of his establishment, while an employer who is a party to an industrial dispute shall be entitled to be represented in any such proceedings by a person duly authorized by him.
If there is a difficulty or doubt as to the interpretation of any provision of a settlement or award under Section 231(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what should be done?
The matter shall be referred to the Tribunal for decision after giving the parties concerned an opportunity of being heard.
What is the purpose of establishing a Participation Fund and a Welfare Fund under Section 233(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The Participation Fund shall be established to provide workers with a share of the profits, while the Welfare Fund shall be established to provide benefits for the welfare of workers.
What does 'Welfare Fund' mean under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The Workers Welfare Fund established under this Chapter.
Who is considered a beneficiary of a company under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

Any person including a probationer who has been employed in the company for not less than 9 (nine) months irrespective of any rank and status, excepting the employer, a partner or a member of the management board.
What percentage of net profit must an employer pay to the Welfare Fund within nine months of the close of every year?

Five percent (5%) of the net profit of the previous year at the proportion of 80:10:10 to respectively the Participatory Fund, Welfare Fund and Workers Welfare Foundation Fund established under section 14 of the Bangladesh Workers Welfare Foundation Act, 2006.
What is considered an 'industry-related activity' for the purposes of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

Activities related to factory, bank, money lending establishment or insurance company run for profit, and transformation, generation, conversion, transmission or distribution of electrical energy including hydraulic power.
How much time does a company have to establish a Workers Participation Fund and a Workers Welfare Fund in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter?
One month from the date on which this Chapter becomes applicable to it.
Who shall be elected by the workers of a company to the Board of Trustees under section 235 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Two members shall be elected by the workers of the company from amongst themselves.
What is the percentage of money deposited to the Welfare Fund that must be deposited to the Workers Welfare Foundation Fund immediately before section 14 takes effect?
50% (of the one percent deposit made by the employer)
How long after a company deposits one percent of its net profit to the Welfare Fund, does the Trustee Board have to deposit the money to the Workers Welfare Foundation Fund?
Immediately before the provision takes effect

What is the procedure for removing a member from the Board of Trustees if the Government suspects that the member is persistently failing in their functions or acting inconsistently with the objects and interests of the Funds?
The Government may, after giving the Board or such member an opportunity of showing cause by order, remove such member from his office
What happens to a member's position on the Board of Trustees if they are removed by the Government under clause (a) of sub-section (5) of section 235?
They shall not be re-elected or nominated to the Board of Trustee.
What is the minimum period of service required for a beneficiary to participate in the Funds?
No beneficiary without completing 6 (six) months of service in a company during a year of account shall participate in the Funds.
How much of the total amount deposited in the Participation Fund is distributed in cash to all beneficiaries every year?
Two-thirds of the total amount deposited in the Participation Fund in every year shall be distributed in equal proportion to all beneficiaries in cash,
What happens to a beneficiary's share in the Funds if they are dismissed from service?
If any beneficiary is dismissed from service, his share in the Funds shall be forfeited.
Can a beneficiary participate in future bonus and right-issues if their shares were acquired through the conversion of the Participation Fund into ordinary equity capital?
Yes, the shares acquired in the manner set out in sub-section (7) shall participate in future bonus and right-issues in the same manner as other shares.
What is the maximum percentage of paid-up capital that the Participation Fund can represent after conversion?
Provided that it, shall not, after such conversion, be more than twenty five percent of the paid-up capital of the company or of 50% (fifty percent) of the additional capital, whichever is less.
What happens to a beneficiary's share in the Funds if they are dismissed from service?
The beneficiary's share in the Funds shall be forfeited.
How are the benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries transferred when they are transferred to another office or unit?

The benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries shall be transferred to the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred, and their service in the previous office or unit shall be counted towards their entitlement to the benefits of the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred.
Who receives full benefits under the Welfare Fund in the event of retirement or death during employment?
The beneficiary himself, or his nominee, shall receive full benefits under this Chapter.
What is an exception to income tax for the Funds and workers' sums paid out of the Funds?

content: The income of the Funds including their capital gains shall be exempted from income tax.
The sums paid out of the Funds to the workers shall be exempted from income tax.

messages.content: What is the responsibility of a company regarding the expenses of the Board of Trustees?
All expenses of the Board of Trustees, including the cost of maintenance of accounts of the Board, shall be borne by the company.
What is the effect of the dissolution of the Dockworkers Management Board under section 263A of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

The dissolution of the Dockworkers Management Board results in the cancellation of the registration of dockworkers and their absorption into the Mongla Port Authority and Chittagong Port Authority, with continuity of employment on similar terms and conditions.
What is the process for the transfer of provident fund, gratuity, and other welfare funds of dockworkers when their management board is dissolved?

The provident fund, gratuity, and other welfare funds of dockworkers are transferred without any charge to the Chittagong Port Authority and Mongla Port Authority, respectively, which shall maintain and administer them.
What is the responsibility of the government in case of ambiguity or difficulty in applying provisions related to the dissolution of management boards?
The Government may issue an order to clarify or explain any provision that causes difficulty in its application.
Can a private sector establishment constitute a provident fund for the benefits of its workers under section 264 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Yes, any establishment in the private sector may constitute a provident fund for the benefits of its workers.
What is the procedure for dealing with debts or liabilities incurred by dockworkers before their management board was dissolved?

The debts or liabilities incurred by dockworkers are deemed to have been incurred by the Chittagong Port Authority and Mongla Port Authority, respectively, after the dissolution of the management boards.
What is the minimum percentage of a worker's monthly basic wages that they must subscribe to the provident fund every month?
Not less than seven percent and not more than eight per cent
Who shall be nominated as representatives of the employer in the Board of Trustees, and who shall be nominated as representatives of the workers?

Representatives of the employer shall be nominated by the employer, while representatives of the workers shall be nominated by the collective bargaining agent or participation committee, whichever is applicable
What is the duration for which members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office, and what happens if they fail to complete their term?
Members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office for a period of two years; they shall continue to hold office until their successors enter upon office
What are the purposes for which at least half of the total accumulations in the provident fund must be invested, and what is the role of the employer in this process?

At least half of the total accumulations in the provident fund must be invested in government securities, including defence and postal saving certificates; the cost of maintenance of the provident fund shall be borne by the employer
What is the deadline for an establishment to make necessary provisions for the constitution of a provident fund if at least three-fourths of the total number of workers demand its creation?
Within six months of the receipt of application; the provident fund shall start operation before the expiry of that period
What is the deadline for submitting a statement of accounts of income and expenditure to the Director General?
Within 1 (one) month of the submission of audit report.
What are the criteria for exempting an establishment from operating under Section 16 of the Act?
The Government may, on application by the employer, exempt an establishment if it is satisfied that the provident fund is working satisfactorily and the workers have no complaints against it.
Who shall be appointed as members of the Board of Trustees for the Tea plantation Workers' Provident Fund?
The Chairman and three members representing employers, three members representing tea workers, and two members who are not connected with the tea industry.
What is the term of office for the Chairman and other members of the Board of Trustees?
Three (3) years from the date of their appointment, unless their successors enter upon office.
How much administrative charge can be levied by the Board of Trustees on the basis of subscription?
The Board of Trustees may levy an administrative charge based on subscription, as fixed by the Government in consultation with the Board.
What is the payment schedule for administrative charges by employers to the Provident Fund?
Employers shall pay the administrative charge within 15 (fifteen) days of the close of every month.
How much percentage of basic wages shall an employer pay as subscription to the provident fund for a worker employed for more than 1 year?
Seven and a half per cent of the basic wages for the time being payable to that worker.
What happens if an employer defaults on payment of subscription to the provident fund or any charges under this Chapter? Can damages be recovered from the employer?
Yes, damages at the rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear can be recovered by the Board of Trustees.
What is protected in case of a worker's death and how does it relate to provident fund payments?
The amount standing to the credit of any worker in his account at the time of his death shall vest in his nominee, subject to any deduction under other laws.
Can an employer reduce wages or amenities due to liability for payment of subscription or charges under this Act?
No, an employer shall not reduce wages or other benefits by reason only of their liability for payment of any subscription or charges under this Act.
What is the penalty for an employer who fails to comply with an order of the Labour Court under section 33?
The employer shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (three) months, or with fine which may extend to 5,000 (five thousand) taka, or with both.
What is the penalty for an employer who employs a child or adolescent in contravention of any provision of the Act?
The employer shall be punished with fine which may extend to 5,000 (five thousand) taka.
If a woman worker works for cash or kind during her permitted period of absence under Chapter IV, what is the penalty?
She shall be punished with fine which may extend to 1,000 (one thousand) taka.
What is the procedure for an employer who has been found guilty of contravention of section 67?

[No specific answer provided in the text, but general information: The Court shall pass an order to the employer concerned to give the worker the benefit under Chapter IV of which he was deprived. Additionally, the Court may impose a fine as per Section 284]
Can an employer delegate its powers to a subordinate officer or person?
Yes, subject to the rules made in this behalf, the competent authority may, by order in writing, delegate all or any of its powers to any person or officer subordinate to him.
What is the maximum fine that can be imposed on an employer who pays wages below the minimum rate of wages?
The maximum fine that can be imposed on an employer who pays wages below the minimum rate of wages is up to 5,000 taka.
How much imprisonment can an employer face for failing to give notice of accidents resulting in serious bodily injury?
An employer can face imprisonment for a term that may extend to 6 months if the accident results in serious bodily injury.
What is the penalty for failure to implement settlement, etc., as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The penalty for failing to implement settlement, etc., is imprisonment for a term that may extend to 2 years or a fine of up to 10,000 taka.
Can a worker be punished with imprisonment for taking part in an illegal strike, as per Section 294 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Yes, a worker can be punished with imprisonment for a term that may extend to 6 months if they take part in an illegal strike.
What is the maximum fine that can be imposed on a person who contravenes provisions of Section 196A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The maximum fine that can be imposed on a person who contravenes provisions of Section 196A is up to 10,000 taka.
What is the punishment for an employer who contravenes section 228(2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 1 (one) year, or with fine which may extend to 5,000 (five thousand) taka, or with both.
What is the penalty for taking part in or instigating a go-slow under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 6 (six) months, or with fine which may extend to 5,000 (five thousand) taka, or with both.

If an employer fails to deposit his own subscription or the subscription of a worker deducted from his wages into the provident fund for more than 3 (three) months without a reasonable excuse, what is he liable for?
He shall be deemed to have misappropriated the money of that provident fund.
What is the punishment for an employee who misappropriates or embezzles funds from a trade union fund with bad intention?
Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 1 (one) year and shall also be liable to fine.
A trade union is registered but its activities are restricted due to section 210(7). What is the penalty for non-compliance with this provision?
Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (three) months, or with fine which may extend to 2,000 (two thousand) taka, or with both.
What is the penalty for using a false certificate of fitness granted to another person?
He shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (three) months or with fine which may extend to 1,000 (one thousand) taka, or with both.
A worker is fined 500 taka for contravening a provision of the Act. Is this amount considered low?

Yes, according to Section 305 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, if any worker employed in an establishment contravenes any provision of the Act or any rules, regulations or schemes, he shall be punished with fine which may extend to 500 (five hundred) taka.
What is the maximum punishment for obstructing an officer acting under the Act?
He shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 6 (six) months, or with fine which may extend to 25,000 (twenty five thousand) taka, or with both.
If an officer demands to see a worker's register or record, but the worker refuses to produce it, what is the consequence?
The worker shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (three) months, or with fine which may extend to 1,000 (one thousand) taka, or with both.
A construction company is fined 2,000 taka for disclosing secret information related to a construction project. Is this amount considered severe?

Yes, according to Section 304 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, if any person discloses, in contravention of any provision of this Act, any secret information relating to any construction or business which has come to his knowledge during discharge of his official duties or any result of an examination under this Act, he shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 6 (six) months, or with fine which may extend to 2,000 (two thousand) taka, or with both.
What is the punishment for an officer who prevents a person from appearing before them or being examined by them?
Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (three) months, or with fine which may extend to 10,000 (ten thousand) taka, or with both.
A worker is injured on the job due to a contravention of workplace safety regulations. What are the possible punishments under Section 309 of the Labour Act?

content: Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 4 (four) years or with fine which may extend to 1,00,000 (one lakh) taka, or with both; if such contravention results in serious bodily injury, with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 2 (two) years, or with fine which may extend to 10,000 (ten thousand) taka, or with both; or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 6 (six) months, or with fine which may extend to 2,000 (two thousand) taka, or with both.

messages.content: What is the penalty for an employer who fails to comply with an order made by the Court under Section 310(1)?
Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 6 (six) months, or with fine which may extend to 2,000 (two thousand) taka, or with both.
Can an employee terminate their employment contract without notice if they are dismissed due to misconduct?
No, as per Section 37 of the Labour Act, an employer is required to give three months' notice to an employee before terminating their employment contract.
How long does a worker have to file a complaint with the Ministry of Labour and Employment if they are dissatisfied with their wages or working conditions?
Within two weeks from the date of receipt of the wages or working condition complaint, as per Section 64 of the Labour Act.
What is the maximum amount of taka that can be paid to a worker as wages, according to Section 311 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Up to 2,000 (two thousand) taka
Who bears the burden of proof regarding a person's age if they are suspected of being under or over a certain age, as per Section 311 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The accused
What is the requirement for a registered medical practitioner to certify the age of a worker, according to Section 312 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
They must have examined the worker and believe that their certified age is accurate
Scenario: An employee has been working for an employer who has refused to pay them their wages on time. According to Section 315 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what should be done next?
The employee can report the contravention to the Director General, Inspector General, or Controller of provident funds
What is the timeframe within which a complaint must be made for a case under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 to be considered valid, as per Section 314?
Within 6 (six) months from the date of commission of the offence
Who is appointed by the Government to specify the jurisdiction or area of each of the Deputy Director, Assistant Director, and Labour Officer under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The Director General
What are some of the powers and functions delegated to an Additional Inspector General by the Inspector General, as per section 5 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

content: To act as Conciliator in any industrial dispute
To supervise the functions of the Participation Committee

messages.content: What is the role of the Establishment Inspectors, ex-officio, for the purposes of regulations made under Chapter VI within their jurisdictions?
Principal officers of the Mercantile Marine Department
In what circumstances can an Inspector General delegate any of his powers and functions to an Additional Inspector General or Joint Inspector General?
By general or special order in writing
What is the requirement for a Labour Inspector to enter, inspect, and examine a place, premises, vessel, or vehicle under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
With necessary assistants, at any reasonable time
What is the primary responsibility of a Labour Inspector under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
To investigate and examine compliance with provisions of the Act, rules, regulations, or schemes in respect of any establishment or worker employed therein.
How does an employer provide necessary means or arrangement for making entries, inspections, examinations, enquiries, or doing acts necessary for Labour Inspectors under the Act?

An employer shall provide such means or arrangement as may be required by a Labour Inspector for making any entry, inspection, examination, enquiry or doing any other act necessary for the exercise of powers or performance of duties under the Act.
What is the requirement for an employer to produce records, registers, and documents for inspection before a Labour Inspector?

Every employer shall be required to produce for inspection before a Labour Inspector all such records, registers, and any other documents as he may require for the purposes of this Act or any rules, regulations, or schemes.
Can a Labour Inspector call for and seize records, registers, or documents from an employer if necessary for enforcement of the Act?

Yes, a Labour Inspector shall have power to call for and seize any record, register, or any other document from any employer in respect of enforcement of this Act or any rules, regulations, or schemes, as he may consider necessary for the purpose of performing duties thereunder.
What is the role of the Controller of Tea Plantation Workers' Provident Fund under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The Controller shall perform his functions under the general control and superintendence of the Board of Trustees, act as the Secretary to the Board, convene meetings of the Board, record and keep records of its minutes, and be responsible for carrying out the decisions of the Board of Trustees.
What are the specific powers granted to the Controller or any person authorized by him under Section (8) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

The Controller or any person authorized by him may enter into tea plantations or premises connected therewith, require production of accounts, registers, or documents relating to employment and payment of wages, and examine the employer, officers, employees, agents, or persons in charge.
What are the steps that a Board must take after an audit report is submitted by the Auditor General under Section (6) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The Board shall take steps forthwith to rectify any defects or irregularities pointed out in the audit report.
Who is responsible for maintaining the accounts of a Board as per Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
A Board shall maintain its accounts in such manner and in such form as the Government may direct.
What is the role of the Auditor General in auditing the accounts of a Board under Section (2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The auditor general shall audit the accounts of income and expenditure of a Board every year in such manner as he deems fit.
What is the purpose of the National Council for Industrial Health and Safety established under Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

The Government may constitute a Council to be called the National Council for Industrial Health and Safety, consisting of various secretaries from different ministries, to oversee industrial health and safety.
What is the minimum notice period required for an employer to inform the Inspector General of a change in management, and by when must this notification be made?
The employer shall send to the Inspector General a written notice of such change within 7 (seven) days from the date on which such person assumes his office.
What is the process for an establishment that does not have a manager appointed, and who will be deemed as the manager in such cases?

During a period when no manager is appointed in an establishment or the person so appointed does not work, any person acting as manager or, if no such person is found, the employer himself shall be deemed to be the manager of that establishment for the purposes of this Act.
What are the procedures for applying permission for construction, extension, or registration of a factory, and what are the timelines for receiving approval?

The Government may require previous permission in writing from the Inspector General for the construction, establishment, or extension of any factory, as well as for registration. The application process must be accompanied by plans, and no order or direction of the Inspector General can be communicated within 3 (three) months from the date of receipt.
What are the options available to an employer if their appeal against a Labour Inspector's order is denied, and what is the timeframe for appealing?
An employer may appeal against a Labour Inspector's order within 30 (thirty) days of receiving such an order. The appellate authority may confirm, modify or set aside the order.
What type of factories are declared as seasonal factories by the Government, and what is the criteria for determining their status?

The Government may declare any factory to be a seasonal factory if it ordinarily carries on manufacturing processes for not more than 180 (one hundred and eighty) working days in a year and cannot be operated except during a particular season or at times dependent on the irregular action of natural forces.
What is the period within which an application for recovery of money under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006 can be entertained?
1 (one) year from the date on which money becomes payable
Can an employer recover fees or money from a worker for providing facilities or supplying equipment or appliances that ought to be provided or supplied by the employer under the Act?
No, except the price for food supplied in the canteen
What is the required behavior towards women employees in an establishment, as per Section 332 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
No person shall behave with a woman in a manner that may seem indecent or unmannerly or repugnant to her modesty or honour
How can an employer recover money from a worker who has not received payment within the specified period?
By attachment and sale of movable properties belonging to the person liable to pay such money, in the manner prescribed by rules
What is the priority given to matters related to payment of dues to workers under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The matter of payment of dues to the worker shall get highest priority
What is the definition of a 'public servant' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

A public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the Penal Code, 1860 (XLV of 1860) includes the Director General, the Inspector General, the Controller of the provident funds, the Chairman of a Labour Court, the Chairman or any member of the Tribunal and any person appointed under Chapter XX.
Can an employer be held liable for damages if they fail to provide necessary provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 in their establishment?

Yes, under section 338(3), the owner of premises shall be required by order of the Inspector General to display notices or posters relating to health, safety, and welfare of workers employed in their establishment.
What is the exception for existing conditions of employment under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Nothing in this Act or any rules, regulations, or schemes shall affect any right or privilege to which a worker was entitled on the date of commencement of this Act under any law repealed by this Act or under any award, agreement, settlement, custom, or usage, so long as he continues to be employed under the employer under whom he was employed on the date of such commencement.
What are some common facilities and services that the owner of premises is liable for providing in certain special circumstances?

The owner of premises shall be liable for providing and maintaining common facilities and services, including approach roads, drainage, water supply, lighting, and sanitation, as well as safe means of access to higher floors and flats.

A worker is employed by an employer under a lease agreement that includes provisions related to health, safety, and welfare. However, the employer fails to comply with these provisions. What can the worker do?

The worker can file a complaint with the Inspector General or a Labour Court, who will investigate and take necessary action against the employer for violating the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.
What is the principle that should be followed in determining wages or fixing the minimum rate of wages for any worker, according to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The principle of equal wages for male, female and handicapped workers for work of equal nature or standard or value
Who can be authorized by a Board to exercise its powers under Section 345 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The Chairman or any of its members or officers authorized in this behalf
What is the purpose of a training course on the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, as stated in Section 348 of the Act?
To organize training courses for officers of trade unions of workers and employers to ensure they are familiar with the provisions of the Act
In case an employer wants to organize a training course on the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 for its employees, who should undertake such training?
An officer of the establishment specified by the employer or at least 50 (fifty) workers employed in the establishment

What is the maximum duration of a training course on the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 that can be organized by a collective bargaining agent or a federation of trade unions, as per Section 348 of the Act?
Not exceeding 7 (seven) days
What is the purpose of displaying notices specifying rates of wages payable to workers in an establishment?
To inform workers about their wages and ensure that employers comply with wage provisions under Chapter XI of the Labour Act.
What is the purpose of maintaining records of weights, measures, and weighing machines kept by employers for payment of wages?
To ensure accuracy in wage payments and compliance with provisions under Chapter XI of the Labour Act.
What is the maximum amount of fine that can be imposed on an employer for violating labor laws in Bangladesh?
1,000 (one thousand) taka
Which laws are hereby repealed under section 353 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The list of repealed laws includes: The Workmen’s Compensation Act, 1923, The Children (Pledging of Labour) Act, 1933, and others.
What happens to any case or proceedings pending in a Court or Tribunal at the time of commencement of this Act?
Such cases shall be continued in and heard and disposed of by such Court or Tribunal, as if such laws were not repealed.
In the event of conflict between the Bangla and English texts of this Act, which text takes precedence?
The Bangla text shall prevail.
What is the purpose of Schedule I in the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, as mentioned in section 2(1) and section 151?
Schedule I lists injuries deemed to result in permanent partial disablement.
What is the minimum period of notice required to be given by an employer before terminating an employment contract, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
As per section 25 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, no notice is required to be given by an employer in case of death, illness or other causes beyond their control
How much percentage of loss of earning capacity will a worker receive if they are permanently disabled and are unable to perform any work for which eye-sight is essential?

As per section 27 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, a worker who loses sight of both eyes to such an extent as to render them unable to perform any work for which eye-sight is essential will receive 100% loss of earning capacity
What are the specific types of injuries that qualify for compensation under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
[List of specified injuries, e.g. amputation of both legs or thighs, severe facial disfigurement, etc.]
Can a worker who has lost their thumb and metacarpal bone claim compensation under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Yes, as per section 30 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, loss of thumb and its metacarpal bone is considered a qualifying injury
How will trade unions be represented in the workplace, and what are their rights under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

As per section 34 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, trade unions have the right to representation in the workplace and must be recognized by employers. The Act also provides for collective bargaining agreements
What are some of the occupations that require special protective gear and are classified as hazardous under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

content: Any occupation where organic or inorganic chemicals are used or handled
Any occupation where any material is handled manually
Any process where jute and cotton fibre are used

messages.content: What is the minimum number of persons required to be employed in a manufacturing process for an establishment to be considered as hazardous under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
5 (five) or more
Who is included in the definition of a worker under Section 150(8) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

content: Any person who is employed, otherwise than in the railway or in a clerical capacity, in connection with the operation or maintenance of a lift or a vehicle propelled by steam or other mechanical power or by electricity
Any person who is engaged in any manufacturing process or in any kind of work whatsoever incidental to or connected with any such manufacturing process

messages.content: What are some common occupational diseases covered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

content: Pathological manifestations due to X-ray, radium and other radioactive substances
Primary epitheliomatous cancer of the skin
Fibrosis of lung

messages.content: What is the procedure for termination of employment in Bangladesh under the Labour Act 2006?
Termination shall be made by giving two months' written notice to the employee, except in cases of misconduct or serious breach of contract, where the employer may terminate immediately
Who is not considered a worker under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any person who is employed as a clerk only in a place or room where no manufacturing process is carried on
What is the maximum number of persons that can be employed for an excavation to be deemed not a mine under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
50 (fifty)
What is the minimum depth requirement for an excavation to be deemed not a mine under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
6 (six) metres
What kind of construction, maintenance, repair or demolition work requires more than 25 persons and explosives to be used, according to Section 18(3)(b) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any construction or excavation work
A worker is employed in a construction project that involves blasting operations. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what type of occupation are they classified under?
Occupation involving blasting operations (Section 17)
Who falls under the category of workers entitled to compensation in case of permanent total disablement?
The worker's monthly wages (as specified in section 143 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006)
What is the rate of compensation payable for temporary disability during the first two months?
Full monthly wages
If a worker dies due to an occupational disease, what amount of compensation is payable?
In case of prolonged occupational disease, how long can the period of disablement exceed in order to receive compensation?
2 (two) years
A worker is employed in the operation of a ferry boat carrying more than 10 persons. What type of occupation falls under section 19 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Section 19 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006 covers workers employed in the operation of any ferry boat capable of carrying more than 10 persons
